ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Technical skills for how to use the cameras, lighting, framing etc

I have learned the basics of filmmaking, film discussion, and analyzation. I learned hands on technical experience (camera, editing), and learned by taking risks. We discussed the ethics of Representation and looked at and discussed the ethics of representation in documentary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course could be more hands on. Charlie is always willing to help which is great, but at times it can be hard to know where to start. It would benefit from a little more guidance.

Strengths: the entire set up has close to no flaws. It provides space and time to work, learn, ask questions, and go outside your comfort zone. I have learned more in this class than many at Yale. 

Weaknesses: the Docu cards could be more geared toward your documentary topic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are clear on what you want to do / create, it can be highly beneficial to the project and enjoyable.
absolutely. film studies majors, or anyone interested in social justice or basically anything they are passionate about and looking for another avenue to spread a message: this is the class for you.
